title: Extra Work on Your Plate
situation: Your manager keeps asking you to ‘quickly’ help with tasks that are not part of your role. Your own work is starting to slip.
question: How do you respond to the next request?

choices.label: Say yes again and plan to work late to catch up.
choices.outcome: Your manager sees you as reliable, but your stress and workload become unsustainable.
choices.insight: Always saying yes can make you look helpful but also silently trains people to overload you.

choices.label: Say, “I can help, but I’ll need to drop something else. Which of my current tasks is less of a priority?”
choices.outcome: Your manager has to consider your workload. Sometimes they reassign the extra task or adjust expectations.
choices.insight: Assertiveness doesn’t always mean saying no; it can mean making trade-offs visible.

choices.label: Avoid your manager and hope they ask someone else instead.
choices.outcome: The pattern might pause, but you miss opportunities to shape how your role is defined.
choices.insight: Avoidance can protect you for a moment but usually leaves the underlying dynamic unchanged.

title: Pushing Back on Unrealistic Deadlines
situation: A stakeholder asks you to deliver something in two days that you know will take at least a week.
question: What do you say?

choices.label: Agree to the deadline and hope you can somehow make it work.
choices.outcome: You’re highly stressed and might deliver rushed work that doesn’t reflect your real ability.
choices.insight: Taking on impossible timelines to please others often hurts quality and your reputation long-term.

choices.label: Say, “For the quality you’re asking for, I’d need about a week. I can share a rough draft in two days if that helps—would that work?”
choices.outcome: They get a clearer picture of what’s possible and can decide between speed and depth.
choices.insight: Offering options shows you’re collaborative, not difficult, while still protecting realistic timelines.

choices.label: Respond with, “That’s impossible,” and leave it at that.
choices.outcome: You’re honest about the problem, but they may feel shut down instead of helped.
choices.insight: Naming limits is important, but pairing them with alternatives keeps the relationship constructive.

title: Speaking Up in a Meeting
situation: You disagree with a decision being made in a meeting, but you’re not the most senior person in the room.
question: How do you express your view?

choices.label: Stay silent to avoid rocking the boat.
choices.outcome: The decision goes ahead unchanged. You feel frustrated and less engaged.
choices.insight: Staying silent protects you from discomfort but can also reduce your influence and learning.

choices.label: Say, “Can I offer a different angle? I’m concerned about X, and here’s why…”
choices.outcome: You may not change the decision, but you add value and are seen as thinking critically.
choices.insight: Framing disagreement as another angle invites discussion rather than conflict.

choices.label: Bluntly say, “This doesn’t make sense,” in front of everyone.
choices.outcome: People may focus more on your tone than the substance of your point.
choices.insight: Strong opinions carry further when they’re wrapped in respect.
